g.text: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Izmir Institute of
Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bartin University,
green synthesis; phosphors; phosphor-converted white LED; white
License and terms: see end of document.
Phosphors can serve as color conversion layers to generate white light with varying optical features, including color rendering index
(CRI), high correlated color temperature (CCT), and luminous efficacy. However, they are typically produced under harsh synthe-
sis conditions such as high temperature, high pressure, and/or by employing a large amount of solvent. In this work, a facile, water-
based, rapid method has been proposed to fabricate lanthanide-doped hydroxide-based phosphors. In this sense, sub-micrometer-
particles (as red phosphor) were synthesized in water at ambient conditions in ≤60 min reaction time. The
doping ratio was controlled from 2.5–20 mol %. Additionally, first principle calculations were performed on Y(OH)
understand the preferable doping scenario and its optoelectronic properties. As an application, these fabricated red phosphors were
composite and used to generate white light. The resulting white light showed a remarkable
improvement (≈24%) in terms of luminous efficiency, a slight reduction of CCT (from 3900 to 3600 K), and an unchanged CRI
Interior lighting is an integral part of civilization, and its devel-
opment has evolved toward the design of more energy efficient
white light generation plays a role in both academic and indus-
trial applications. To obtain white light through LED-based
configurations, either all three primary colors (red–green–blue
